Declan Rice (born 14 January 1999) is an English professional footballer who plays as a defensive midfielder for Premier League club Arsenal and the England national team. Known for his stamina, strength, ball carrying ability and tackling, he is regarded as one of the best defensive midfielders in the world.[3][4][5]

Rice began his professional career at West Ham United, having been released by Chelsea's academy, and established himself as a key first-team player by 2017. In 2022, he succeeded Mark Noble as club captain, and led the club to a UEFA Europa Conference League title the following year, as well as being named the competition's Player of the Season. After making 245 appearances for West Ham, Rice was signed by Arsenal in July 2023 for a club record fee of £100 million, making him the joint-most-expensive English player in history.

Eligible to play for England or the Republic of Ireland, Rice represented the Republic of Ireland internationally at both youth and senior levels prior to 2019. He subsequently changed his national allegiance and made himself available for selection by England. Rice made his England debut in 2019 and has represented the country at UEFA Euro 2020, the 2022 FIFA World Cup, and Euro 2024.

Early life and career

Declan Rice[6] was born on 14 January 1999[7] in Kingston upon Thames, Greater London, where he was raised.[8] His paternal grandparents were from Douglas, County Cork, in Ireland.[9] He joined the academy of Chelsea in 2006, as a seven-year-old.[10][11]

In 2013, after his release at age 14, he joined the academy of West Ham United after a trial period in the spring.[12][13] West Ham United Academy coach Trevor Bumstead stated it was Rice's determination and persistence that helped him break through the ranks at West Ham.[14] Rice won the Premier League Cup in 2016 with the under-21s and the Premier League 2 Division 2 in 2020 with the under-23s.[15]

Club career

West Ham United

2015–2020

Rice playing for West Ham United in 2019

On 16 December 2015, two years after joining West Ham United at youth level, Rice signed his first professional contract with the club.[16] Rice received his first call-up to the West Ham senior squad for the games against Sunderland and Everton in April 2017, after impressing in the under-23 team.[17] He made his senior debut against Burnley on the last day of the 2016–17 Premier League season, coming on as a 91st-minute substitute for Edimilson Fernandes in a 2–1 away win,[18][19] five days after captaining the under-23s to promotion with a 2–1 win away to Newcastle United.[20] His first-team debut came on 19 August 2017 in a 3–2 defeat at Southampton.[21] In April 2018, Rice was named as runner-up for the 2017–18 Hammer of the Year award behind Marko Arnautović.[22]

On 22 December 2018, he made his 50th appearance for West Ham,[23][24] becoming the first player to do so while still a teenager since Michael Carrick.[25][26] On 28 December 2018, Rice signed a new contract until 2024 with the option of an additional year.[27] On 12 January 2019, Rice scored his first goal for West Ham and was named man of the match in a 1–0 win against Arsenal, in West Ham's 50th Premier League game at the London Stadium.[28] On 20 April, Rice was named on the shortlist for the PFA Young Player of the Year award, which was eventually awarded to Rice's England teammate Raheem Sterling.[29] At the end of the 2018–19 season, he was named the Players' Player of the Year and won the award for Individual Performance of the Season, for his match winning game against Arsenal, and was named the Young Hammer of the Year for the third-consecutive season.[30]

**Declan Rice: From Chelsea's Reject to Arsenal's Star – A Comedy of Midfield Errors!**

In the whimsical world of football, where fortunes can change faster than a cat on a hot tin roof, one young lad named Declan Rice has taken the scenic route to stardom. Born on January 14, 1999, in Kingston upon Thames — where the Thames is usually more fashionable than its namesake — Declan joined Chelsea's academy at the ripe old age of seven, only to be released like a helium balloon at a kid's birthday party. But fear not! He found refuge at West Ham United, where he flourished like a weed in a neglected garden.

By 2017, Declan was strutting around the pitch like he owned it, eventually donning the captain's armband and leading West Ham to a UEFA Europa Conference League title faster than you can say "That’s a lot of gobbledeegook!" Fast forward to July 2023, and Declan made the big move to Arsenal for a jaw-dropping £100 million, proving he’s not just good at tackling but also shockingly good at finding the right bank!

Declan's talent is so vast that it's like trying to hide an elephant in a room full of tigers. With his stamina, strength, and tackling prowess, he's been labeled one of the world’s top defensive midfielders. And yes, we’re talking about a man who’s not afraid to kick a rogue ball out of the way while ensuring his hair stays effortlessly tousled!

He’s even swapped national allegiances, going from representing Ireland to putting on an England jersey, as if he decided to trade in his car for a shiny new sports model. Since debuting in 2019, Declan's been a fixture for England, gracing tournaments like the 2020 Euros and the 2022 World Cup. Who knew that the lad who once couldn’t make the Chelsea cut would become one of the joint-most-expensive English players in history? 

In the end, Declan Rice is living proof that sometimes, getting dropped from a football academy may just be the kick in the shin you need to become a superstar — or, as Craig Ferguson would say, a grand comedy that could make even the most stoic football fan break into laughter! 

Now, let’s hope he keeps those tackles sharp and his hair even sharper!
